displayed_text: Patient: That’s a different study. Doctor: Because that only works against the bone. Patient: Oh. Doctor: So unless I see and okay the bone scan, I was just looking, they did they compared it to a two-thousand-fourteen bone scan. So I really cannot tell too much. The only new findings are really this one on your bone scan – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: and that we are very well aware about that we know. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So those were there even before you started the Xofigo. Patient: Right. Doctor: The radiation. Patient: Right. Doctor: So right now I think we will be in just watch and wait mode because I see no recompelling reason to put you on a new treatment.

Patient: That is good news. Doctor: So. So from my standpoint that’s really great news. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um, because we knew there was cancer, and so now we know sort of about where it is. So the question is, is how do we proceed – Patient: Yes. Doctor: - uh to try and get rid of this. Um, and uh you know uh I certainly have no it’s easy for me to say; I have no regrets that you did that clinical trial. Patient: I don’t. Doctor: I think that you know it primed your immune system to help us for the rest of the way here. Uh it’s not something that we can measure, but it’s clearly um something that I’m glad you did. And it certainly didn’t cause the cancer to spread any more or anything like that. Patient: Well my quality of life is significantly better. Doctor: Good, good. How well are you controlling your urine right now? Patient: I’m good. I have a um. Family Member: He has a panty liner.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: One caveat is, and this is going to seem more paradoxical, is that where patients go in this high-risk testosterone trial, the Transformer Trial, they also have to continue the Lupron. Patient: Lupron. Doctor: Which is a hormone-suppression. Patient: Yeah, yeah, we’ve had that before. Doctor: And that may seem paradoxical to you because on the one hand I’m telling you we’re going to give you testosterone back, and on the other hand I’m telling you we’re going to be giving you Lupron to suppress the testosterone. And it turns out this this is exactly what we want to do. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the purpose of this therapy, which we also call bipolar androgen therapy or BAT for short. We call it bipolar, not because it makes the patients bipolar. Doctor: But because we reach two extreme opposite levels of testosterone, opposite poles. Patient: Excuse me; does it have to be Lupron or it could be another hormone? Doctor: It has to be an injectable testosterone-lowering medication. It doesn’t have to be specifically Lupron. It can be any of the injectable hormone therapies. It cannot be an oral hormone therapy. Patient: Right. Okay, okay. Doctor: And typically it’s one of the hormone therapies that’s injected either every three months or every six months.

Patient: Well no. (laughs) Doctor: And that was for your liver right? Patient: I guess so. Doctor: Yeah, So that’s different for your hepatitis. Patient: Now she says go down lower though. Doctor: Yes. So that side perfect. That will be helpful but not enough for us. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we gotta go on a different hunt. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: What you… Doctor: Well good. You’re otherwise feeling okay? You look like a million buck from the, I mean I feel like I haven’t seen you in ages because I haven’t seen you in ages.

Patient: Put you in a hotel? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Hum. And that’s in what town? Doctor: No. I’ll tell you. I can find out. (Laughs) Patient: There’s no way, there’s no way of getting that? What medicine is that they give you for it? Doctor: It’s not the medicine. It’s the scan that is a specific one. That scanner is not available here or around here. Family Member: The scan will detect-? Doctor: If you have the PSMA. If you have that antigen or not in your cells. Then that will help us decide whether we put you on the study or not. Patient: And you can’t get it here in the states? Doctor: Not yet. Family Member: The scan. Doctor: The scan you can get.

Healthcare Professional: What did you give him because I have him coming back for the spinal? Doctor: He’ll come back after he gets scanned which will probably be like in a week or two. Healthcare Professional: Okay, so then we will, because he’s due to come back on the 18th and he’ll have research labs then, so that will be a different one. Doctor: I think so. We’ll try to make sure that we have a plan. Healthcare Professional: Okay Doctor: He can’t get rid of us now. Sit tight.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.10 or more times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::10 or more times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.disagree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::disagree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.12 years or completed high school: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::12 years or completed high school

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White
What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And it’s creeping up, so about three or four months ago twice in the thirties. The normal testosterone for a man of your age would be around a hundred and fifty or two hundred. When we checked your last blood test about two weeks ago it had gone up to fifty-eight. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So it’s slowly increasing. Patient: Right. Doctor: That would mean at least in theory that your fatigue should begin to get better, although the increase has been very recent, so it may not have given your body the time to adjust to that higher level of testosterone. And with time if you remain off of the hormone therapy like you’re currently doing despite your age it may continue to increase further. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So my hope is that with time the fatigue will get better. Patient: Is that a good thing because the testosterone feeds cancer, right? Doctor: Well, it’s a good thing and a bad thing. It’s a double-edged sword. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: But you and I made the decision when we first met after a discussion with Dr.__ as well – Dr. – Patient: Uh huh.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: That’s a good idea. Just write them down though that way… Family Member: We’re not taking up a room? You want us to go back in the lobby? Doctor: If they need you to go to the lobby we’ll let you know. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Alright and did I – yeah you got your copy of – well this is your CAT scan and a copy too. Patient: Merci Beaucoup. Doctor: Hope for the best right? Patient: I’m still recovering from the call and everybody keeps pushing their hand out. Why don’t you do the fist bump? Doctor: Yeah the first bump. Yeah I guess I should get with the times. Patient: I guess the fist bump is less contagious isn’t it? Doctor: Okay now maybe. Yeah you’re right. Although my son has told me that is -

Patient: Right. Doctor: Because everybody gets the hormones. Patient: Right. Doctor: And if we decide to do the chemotherapy it’s because we think it’s the right thing for you - Patient: Okay. Doctor: And the clinical trial is just sort of you know on top of that to see whether or not we add an additional medicine. Patient: Okay, so let me ask you a question. So what is the next thing to do? Doctor: Yeah, so that; we have talked about that. You know your kidney function has gotten better. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You know so that is one of the key parts about you being eligible, that if your kidney function was too high, makes it difficult for us to use chemotherapy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Chemotherapy with your numbers today, you could certainly go ahead and start moving forward with that and picking a date. You know for you to do the clinical trial then we do have to have you; D___ even kept an eye on you and let me know that you were in the hospital. You know we’ve got all kinds of I think Dr._____ one note said that Family Member: No, we’ve been communicating by email. So we were in

Patient: I know. Okay. Family Member: Um. Healthcare Professional: Let me get your reports copied. Family Member: Do you mind if we, is it possible to sit in here and read through the consent? Just so we have… Doctor: That’s fine. It’s just that do you want to - are you okay with doing that? Patient: No, no, let’s take our time. Family Member: Okay. Alright. I didn’t mean not to take it home- Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: -but I meant if questions come up we could ask them. Doctor: Oh I see what you mean. Family Member: Let’s read it through in here and see if we have questions. I’m not asking you to sign it. Doctor: Yeah. Okay and then that way you – you know I’ll check back with you if you have questions.

Family Member: If you could maybe have somebody Google or you Google fluorescence and just see what it’s got that wild Doctor: Okay. Patient: Flor-essence. Doctor: Okay. Flor-essence. Done. Nice to see you. Hello. Hello. Hello. And Good-bye. Do you have enough to eat and drink? Feeling better? Patient: So. Yeah. Oh. I wanted to go to Hospital DR. How do I get to Hospital DR from here? How do I get to DR from here? Can I get a navigator? Doctor: Oh. Yeah a navigator. I couldn’t explain it if my life depended on it, and I’ve been here fourteen years. Doctor: Bye guys. I’m happy you can get Family Member: Bye.

Family Member: Oh, yeah, that’d be great. Patient: So, that’ll be two then. We’ll have two going on at the same time. Doctor: Right. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you’ll keep your Xtandi, Family Member: Xtandi, okay. Doctor: and then we’ll throw on a second medication. Patient: What are the names of the other two drugs? Doctor: No names. All letters and numbers. Family Member: Good. Doctor: Poof! You just turn into a guinea pig again. You were there before, but yeah. I think that’s the hard part. It’s umm, you know, they don’t give names unless it’s moving along the path of development. Umm. And then uh, it’s sorta like you don’t name your pet…you don’t think you’re gonna keep it. I don’t know. Patient: Ahhh.

Patient: So I think I'll stay the course and then we'll see what happens after that. Because I'm pretty good watching. If anything is swelling or if I’m having any pain. I'll be a little more vigilant now to go to the doctor whereas before I'm like. Doctor: Hopefully it doesn’t happen while you’re on the medicine. Patient: Right, no, I'm saying if I got off of it, I'd be a little more vigilant about the idea that if I have swelling, I should go to the doctor because it might not just be me being a macho jock, but I have a problem. Doctor: And so what I hear you say- is that you just got a prescription and how long is that going to be for? Patient: I think that's for three more months. Doctor: So that would be your plan to sort of go and then stop for six months. Healthcare Professional: Okay Patient: Yeah. That works for me. Doctor: Yeah. Blood work, Aximun scan. You're not on MyChart? Patient: I tried to get on MyChart, but the little number that he sent me, died or whatever. Doctor: Yeah, but I can we can print out a new one for you today. Patient: Okay good. Doctor: And then if you can just MyChart message me your email-

Patient: No, no. Doctor: Bowels working okay? Patient: Yep. Family Member: But it went from one side to the other which and he does have kidney stones, but last night it was on this side, this morning that one stopped and it was on this side. Doctor: And now it’s gone? Patient: Yeah. I had a little bit over here on this side, but I mean I think it’s my back because I’ve had back… Family Member: Because kidneys wouldn’t do that. It wouldn’t push back and forth like that. Doctor: No and if it’s the lymph nodes that are pushing, there may be a little bit of pain from that. Family Member: From one side to the other but.. Doctor: Yeah. But it’s still, it doesn’t sound cancer related. It almost sounds muscle or… Family Member: I think his back’s out of whack. Doctor: Or back.

Family Member: Can, can you draw blood today for that? Doctor: Oh, we already have. Family Member: Oh. Okay. Doctor: I’ve just got to, so it was part of the study. Family Member: Oh. Okay. Doctor: We also have a blood test here that we do. But you’ve already done it. I just need to call the lab and found out. You’ve probably done it like four times actually. Patient: Yeah. You have. Doctor: Because we did it before the testosterone, during the testosterone, during the enzalutamide, and we try to look at how those treatments affect it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I’ll, I’ll find out. Patient: Alright. Doctor: So- Family Member: I wanted, I want your input, uh but we couldn’t just give him that - because he is all at that level of three injections of testosterone, he’s a perfect candidate just for that immune thing just to see? (Beeping)
